paper_metadata.title: Modeling of Energy Consumption in Milling Process to Assess their Environmental Impact

process_parameters.spindle_speed: Experiments used spindle speeds ranging from 3500 rpm to 7000 rpm.
process_parameters.feed_rate: Experiments used feed rates: 300, 1000, and 3000 mm/min.
process_parameters.cutting_depth: Radial depth of cut (ae): 0.5 to 4 mm, Axial depth of cut (ap): 0.5 to 4 mm

energy_data.energy_usage: Experiments are based on laboratory measurements and model estimations. Specific values depend on the chosen parameters.
energy_data.power_consumption: Idle power: 275.76 W, Axis power is based on linear regressions, Spindle Power ranges from 43.86 W to 932.37 W depending on RPM, Cutting Power varies with parameters.
energy_data.measurement_method: Yokogawa WT500 power analyzer, Trace function on Siemens Sinumerik 828D CNC controller

kpi_metrics.specific_energy_consumption: Ranges depending on cutting parameters, approximately 1.333 Wh/cm3 for face milling example.
kpi_metrics.CO2_emissions: Ranges depending on electricity source, approximately 3.9 g CO2-eq per functional unit for face milling example.
kpi_metrics.efficiency: Model precision fluctuates depending on parameters, e.g. cutting depth, milling method and MRR.  Error of cutting power, 𝑃𝑐𝑢𝑡𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑔 is displayed in cut #12 (ap = 3 mm, ae = 10 mm, down-milling), where the model underestimates by -7.4 %.
other_kpis: The cutting tool consumption contributes 98 % to 99 % of the total environmental impact in face milling process.

additional_notes: The paper focuses on developing a method for creating a dry milling energy consumption model based on mechanistic modeling principles to assess the environmental impact, specifically the indirect GHG emissions, of milling processes. The key contribution is a practical framework for assessing the environmental impact and providing insights for energy efficiency improvements.
